Actually they weren’t. That needs to be qualified. They weren’t Italians (who never had their hearts in the whole thing anyway and were sensible if not brave about it). Their incredible courage was a considerable threat. Do the math. Any unit that needs to be killed to a man to be destroyed will multiply the otherside’s casualties proportionately. That said their tactics and weaponry were usually behind. They could make an island fortress a hard nut to crack. But any time a position that is stormed gets several times the casualties it inflicts that is a good indicator that there is something flawed about their concepts to begin with. They started off winning victories. But it must be remembered that the side that triggers a war always wins the first round by virtue of choosing where to strike. That seldom allows a knockout. In Burma most of the Imperial forces were in Africa leaving a small portion of second string units. The retreat was handled poorly and the Japanese were willing to divert offroad where the Imperial forces were not: this gave the reputation that they were “natural jungle fighters”. In fact of course the Indian Army had been fighting in jungle for centuries long before Japan sought ambitions outside it’s terrain which does not contain tropical rain forest. Once they were brought to bay their weaknesses started to tell. The absurd theatrical displays of banzai charges wasted lives which would have been better used evacuating them, or if not as guerillas. The island fortresses had ingenious constructions but were ultimately vulnerable to defeat in detail. Basically the IJA was used to fighting Chinese who were not at their best state of performance at the time. The fact was that the Allies had to be willing to take enough casualties to defeat the Japanese. As it happened they were. They also had to learn how to defeat them, which in fact they did. All this can be interpreted as contempt for them. It isn’t so much as downplaying that reputation. The fact is a lot of the fighting had to devolve to attrition (New Guinea was sort of a Pacific Stalingrad and well earned it’s infamous reputation). It did so because Japanese were willing to force such fights in the hope that the Allies would not be able to take it and would sue for peace. As it happens the Allies could take it and in any case had the technical ability to reduce this aspect. In fact this is the only way the Japanese could have won was simply to exasperate the Allies into leaving the field to them. The difference in resources was just that great and the IJA was not such an advanced force as to make up for that. Now the IJN was different. It was a first class navy. Like the IJA it was following the “exasperation” strategy, but with this difference, that they could in fact strike solid blows which ability the IJA was limited in once they got past such freaks as Singapore. The IJN, properly used could have struck wide ranging mobile blows, rather than being tethered to the army as it to often was.
